[h1]Freemium at it's worst.[/h1]

Publisher who doesn't give two fucks about their playerbase, nickle-and-diming them as much as they absolutely can. BattlePass (with no premium currency rewards therein  with which to re-purchase the next battlepass) is $10; short, meaningless "story" missions are $15.

They've successfully addicted their players to the game, who now can't stop no matter how much bullshit, pain, and money-grubbing they endure.

They are a small indie company, they make mistakes!

Overwatch 2 is the culmination of seven years of mismanagement and competitive reworks. When Overwatch launched it was a very casual game, but as it progressed through its lifespan the game was changed to be more and more of a competitive experience to appeal to people who like that kind of thing and the e-sports crowd. This is not inherently a bad thing, but due to the Overwatch team (by their own admission) not understanding what made the game special in the first place, that spark that made me and so many other people fall in love with Overwatch was lost somewhere along the way. Now not only is the original casual experience completely gone, the competitive experience offers less enjoyment than basically every other competitive game on the market right now for many reasons, primarily that the core of the game is just not tailored to that kind of experience, especially after the switch from 6v6 to 5v5.

If you're interested in Overwatch because of what it used to be, be warned. That game is dead and gone. In its current state Overwatch offers nothing that you cannot get from a different competitive game, especially considering the slow pace of content updates that the game has been plagued with even before development went on hiatus in 2019.

And if you're interested in the story missions, 15$ can get you a lot more than an hour and a half of content. Hell, Deep Rock Galactic is on sale for less than that right now, and you can play as four dwarves in that game. Last time I counted you can only play one dwarf in Overwatch. You do the math on that one.

[h1][b]Overhyped and Underdelivered: The Sad Reality of Overwatch 2[/b][/h1]
[b][u]TL;DR[/u][/b]
¬ª The reason why I installed this on Steam is to solely leave a negative review. The only thing not covered behind a paywall in this game is the free download. This piss poor excuse of a sequel is seriously underwhelming, and the disgusting community is literally fed through p*rn content. [b][i]DO NOT PLAY IT.[/i][/b]

¬ª Like most people who played the original Overwatch, everyone eagerly awaited the release of [b]Overwatch 2[/b] with high hopes and expectations. Unfortunately, that excitement turned into disappointment delving into the sequel. [i]Blizzard[/i] took everything that made the first game enjoyable and tossed it out the window.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
¬ª First off, the graphics and design are an absolute letdown. Overwatch‚Äôs charm lays in its vibrant and unique character designs, but Overwatch 2 seems to have taken a detour into the uncanny valley. The characters now look like they are trying too hard to be realistic, and the once-celebrated art style has been replaced with a mishmash of uninspired visuals that lack the original‚Äôs personality.

[h1]Unbalanced Gameplay[/h1]
¬ª Gameplay-wise, it is a mess. The new ‚ÄúPvE emphasis‚Äù they touted feels like a cheap attempt to cash in on the co-op trend. The missions are repetitive and lack the dynamic objectives that made the original game‚Äôs matches so engaging. It is as if the developers thought that throwing in waves of enemies would automatically translate to fun gameplay. Spoiler alert: it doesn‚Äôt. What‚Äôs worse, balancing issues from the first game seemed to have followed the developers into Overwatch 2, and perhaps even worsened. The new heroes are either overpowered or utterly useless, leaving players frustrated as they navigate through uneven matches. The development team practically tossed the concept of playtesting out the window and crossed their fingers, hoping for the best.

[h1]Horrible Story[/h1]
¬ª The much-anticipated story mode falls face flat. While the idea of delving into the backstories of the beloved characters was intriguing, the execution was lackluster at best. The narrative feels disjointed, and the emotional arcs are rushed and fail to make a lasting impact. It is clear that the focus was more on quantity than quality when it came to the story content.

[h1]Pay-To-Win[/h1]
¬ª And let‚Äôs not even get started on the microtransactions and monetization. The game seems to have taken a page out of the worst kind of free-to-play models, with players bombarded by loot boxes and cosmetics that cost an arm and a leg. The game‚Äôs approach to cosmetics feels predatory and overly aggressive. It is evident that [i]Blizzard[/i] is more interested in squeezing money out of players than providing a satisfying and rewarding progression system.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
¬ª All in all, Overwatch 2 feels like a rushed attempt to cash in on the popularity of the original, without understanding what made the first game special. It is a shadow of its predecessor, and I cannot help but feel that the developers have let down their loyal fanbase. Save your money and stick to the original Overwatch ‚Äì at least there, you will find the magic that Overwatch 2 sorely lacks.

[h1][b]Score: 4.5/10[/b][/h1]

[b][i]Was this review helpful?[/i][/b]
¬ª If so, please leave a rating. Awards are also greatly appreciated!
